metadata.title: Experimental investigations on thermal properties of nano-SiO2/paraffin phase change material (PCM) for solar thermal energy storage applications

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 22 December 2018 Revised 6 March 2019 Accepted 7 April 2019
KEYWORDS Thermal energy storage; phase change material; characterization of phase change material; nano-SiO2 /paraffin; SiO2 nanoparticles

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Unceasing supply of thermal energy during the demand period is highly challenging, while conniving the solar thermal systems such as solar water heaters, solar air heaters, solar distillation, solar driers and other solar thermal applications (Da Cunha and Eames 2016; Kaygusuz 1999). Energy from the sun is only available during a limited period of time and it is highly unpredictable, because of dynamic weather and climatic conditions from time to time (Kaygusuz 2003; Sharshir et al. 2017). Hence, it becomes necessary to design the solar thermal systems with suitable arrangement, which could supply the thermal energy irrespective of the dynamic behavior of solar energy. This could be possible, only with the help of appropriate thermal energy storage. Thermal energy can be stored in the form of sensible heat, latent and in terms chemical reactions depending on the capability of thematerial. Amid the different forms of energy storagematerials, phase changematerials considered to be themost effective, because of their greater energy density which in term helps to store vast quantity of thermal energy in the form of latent heat (Farid et al. 2004; JianShe et al. 2019; Karaipekli, Sari, and Kaygusuz 2009; Sari et al. 2013). An extensive research was conducted on different types phase change materials such as organic and inorganic phase change materials

to evaluate their capability to be incorporated as energy storage materials (Cabeza et al. 2011; Ibrahim et al. 2017). Comparatively, paraffin wax has been experimented by most of the researchers, as energy storage material, because they are superior in large energy density, low vapor pressure, good chemical and thermal stability, less supercooling, non-toxicity, large availability and low cost (Shukla, Kant, and Sharma 2017; Xiao, Zhang, and Li 2013). Despite the aforementioned superior quality of paraffin, they lack with their low thermal conductivity (Anghel et al. 2014; Karaipekli et al. 2017). The literatures had come-up with the solutions of improving the thermal conductivity of paraffin wax in different ways such as imparting porous materials in paraffin (Zhong et al. 2010a, 2010b; Huang et al. 2017), adding high conductivity (metallic and non-metallic) particles (Şahan and Paksoy 2017;Wu et al. 2010; Zeng et al. 2007), and by immersing highly conductive metallic fins in PCMs (Khodadadi and Hosseinizadeh 2007). Among the existing methods, the dispersion of highly conductive nanoparticles in paraffin wax becomes the interest of the most of the researchers as it contributes an appreciable enhancement in thermal conductivity of base PCM (Ahmed et al. 2017; Ibrahim et al. 2017; Liu et al. 2015).Wang et al. (2009) concluded that the dispersion of 2.0%mass fraction of multi-walled carbon nanotubes in paraffin wax improved the thermal conductivity ratios to 35–40%. Karaipekli et al. (2017) experimentally studied the effect of 0.3, 0.5 and 1.0 mass percentage of carbon nanotubes on the thermal conductivity of the expanded perlite/paraffin composite phase change material. They acknowledged that the thermal conductivity of the compositewas augmented to 113.3%with 1.0 mass percent of carbon nanotubes. An experimental investigation on paraffin with zinc oxide nanoparticles revealed that the incorporation of zinc oxide nanoparticles improved the thermal properties of paraffin, and it was suggested to be suitable for solar thermal energy storage applications (Şahan and Paksoy 2017).
It is vividly comprehended that themost of the literatures have been found to be dealt with the dispersion of carbon-based particles (JianShe et al. 2019; Karaipekli et al. 2017; Wang et al. 2009; Yu et al. 2008), and nanoparticles of metallic and metal oxides in the base PCMs (Kalaiselvam, Parameshwaran, and Harikrishnan 2012; Lin and Al-Kayiem 2012) to assess their effect on thermal properties of the base PCM. Nevertheless, the impact of non-metallic nanoparticles on the thermal properties of paraffin wax is seldom found in the available literatures. Yang et al. (2014) studied the influence of silicon nitride nanoparticles on the thermal properties of paraffin and they evidently documented in a positive way that the thermal conductivity of paraffin was improved with the increase in mass percentage of silicon nitride nanoparticles. Since then, the detailed study on the thermal properties of paraffin, with any other siliconbased nanoparticles is hardly ever found in the recent literatures. This motivates to comprehensively investigate the ability of low mass% SiO2 nanoparticles being used as the nano additive in paraffin wax for enhancing its thermal properties. By thismeans, this paper becomes novel to explore the opportunity for finding the potential use of nano-SiO2/paraffin as nano-enhanced phase change material in solar heating applications.
The objective of this work is to experimentally analyze the several thermophysical properties of paraffin wax by adding nano-SiO2 particles in three different mass fractions. The experimental results of nano-SiO2 /paraffin PCMs are then compared with that of pure paraffin wax.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text: In thiswork, the candlemaking commercial-grade paraffinwax is used as base PCM, because, this paraffin is more economical than any other type of technical grade paraffin with desired thermophysical properties. The paraffin wax was procured from Jayam Chemicals, Coimbatore. The melting point of paraffin wax, reported by the supplier is in the range between 56°C and 60°C,which is commendable to be used as thermal energy storagemedium in solar heating applications. SiO2 nanoparticles of 15 nmaverage sizewere supplied by Sisco Research Laboratories Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai. The thermophysical properties of the pure paraffin wax and SiO2 nanoparticles are presented in Table 1.

sections.heading: Preparation of nano-sio2/paraffin PCM
sections.text: The nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM was prepared by dispersing different mass% of nano-SiO2 particles in pure paraffin wax. The researchers recommend to disperse low mass% of nanoparticles in the range of 0.2–4%, in order to elude the agglomeration of the particles and to avoid unsolicited increase of material cost (Cai et al. 2011; Kumar and Mylsamy 2018; Wang et al. 2009). Hence, the mass% chosen in this investigation is 0%, 0.5%, 1.0%, and 2.0% of nano-SiO2 particles in paraffin wax. The nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM samples were prepared by two-step method (Amin et al. 2017). Initially, the paraffin wax was heated to the temperature of 70°C in a hot water bath and then kept on a magnetic stirrer. Then, the required mass% of nano-SiO2 particles was gently added to the melted paraffin wax and the nanocomposite PCM was simultaneously heated and stirred for 1-hour duration. Further, the mixture was kept in an ultrasonic vibrator and sonicated for another 2 hours, to avoid agglomeration of the nanoparticles and to obtain a uniform homogeneous mixture. The compositions of samples prepared with different ratios of nano-SiO2/paraffin are presented in Table 2. The samples were molded into cylindrical form for further characterization as shown in Figure 1.

sections.heading: Characterization of nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM
sections.text:
The prepared samples of nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs (0%, 0.5%, 1.0% and 2.0% by mass of nano-SiO2) were further characterized with different apparatuses to analyze their morphology and to evaluate their thermal properties.
The surface morphology and microstructure of the pure paraffin and nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs were analyzed by field emission scanning electronmicroscope (FESEM) using a Zeiss Sigma FESEM, which uses Everhart-Thornley type (SE2) detector for imaging. The size distribution of the commercially procured SiO2 nanoparticles was verified in terms of their diameters, with the help of Zetasizer AT supplied by Melvern. Spectrum two Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer made by PerkinElmer was used to investigate chemical bonding and molecular level behavior of the prepared samples.
Thermal properties, such as melting and solidification points and latent heats of the nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs were studied by Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC). DSC was accompanied with the aid of DSC 6000 with Pyris 6 DSC manufactured by PerkinElmer Inc. TGA 4000 Thermogravimetric Analyzer made by PerkinElmer Inc., was utilized to assess the degradation temperature and weight loss percentage of nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs in order to determine their thermal stability at higher operating temperatures. The thermal conductivity of the samples was measured with KD2 Pro thermal properties analyzer, which is fundamentally operated under transient line heat source method.

sections.heading: FESEM analysis
sections.text: The surface of the pure paraffin wax and nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM samples was scanned with the help of FESEM, and the images are presented in Figure 2. In order to avoid themelting of paraffin wax by scanning electrons, the low-resolution scanning is opted. Primarily, the samples were coated with gold for making them to be conductive. Then, the samples had been imaged with FESEM by shooting electrons over them. The image of paraffin wax reveals that its structure is formed as bundle of stratums. These bundles were faded with the increase in mass% of nano-SiO2 particles in the base PCM. Also, the images confirmed that the agglomeration of the nanoparticles was negligent and the proper physical interaction of nanoparticles with the base PCM was ensured.

sections.heading: Particle size analysis
sections.text: The nano-SiO2 particles were tested for ensuring their size distribution as mentioned by the supplier. Figure 3 shows the bar chart of size distribution obtained using Zetasizer. It could be noticed that the particle size of 15–19.9 nm diameter showed maximum distribution of 21.4%, followed by 20–24.9 nm diameter which contributes 18.2%. Hence, it is fit in the suppliers’ specification (15 nm average size distribution of SiO2 nanoparticles). Moreover, this particle size analysis ensured the correctness in the use of aforesaid nanoparticle size for various characterization tests.

sections.heading: FT-IR analysis
sections.text:
The results of the FT-IR analysis carried out on the paraffin wax and the different samples of nanoSiO2/paraffin PCM have been presented in Figure 4. The analysis revealed that the peak wavelength of the paraffin wax did not substantially change with the addition of the nano-SiO2 particles in different mass%. Two strong peaks of wavelength 2848 cm−1 and 2916 cm−1 depict the medium symmetrical C-H stretching vibration and strong asymmetrical C-H stretching vibration,
Figure 1. Photograph of the prepared nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM samples.
respectively. Likewise, the sharp peaks at 729 cm−1 and 1462 cm−1 represent medium rocking
peak of 1102 cm−1 has been found in the samples containing nano-SiO2 particles of different mass%. This indicates the very strong asymmetrical Si-O-C stretching vibration and proves the strong bonding of SiO2 nanoparticles with the carbon of paraffin. From Figure 4, it is observed that the bonding of SiO2 nanoparticles is strong and concurrently did not disturb the chemical structure of paraffin wax.

sections.heading: DSC analysis
sections.text:
The differential scanning calorimetry results of the nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM samples are presented in Figure 5. The DSC plots of the samples can be observed with two kinds of peaks. The initial peak during the heating is due to the solid to solid transformation in the PCMs, whereas the larger peak demonstrates the solid to liquid phase transformation of the PCMs. During the solid to solid phase transformation, the crystalline structure of PCM breaks and changes from one form to other form. Mohamed et al. (2017) and Murugan et al. (2018) has also complied with the same kind of plots when they investigated the paraffin wax with multi-walled carbon nanotubes and α nano alumina, respectively. However, the solid to liquid phase transformation is the key factor in paraffin wax which stores a substantial amount of heat energy in the form of latent heat. The observed values of the melting temperature, solidification temperature and the corresponding latent heats of the nanoSiO2/paraffin PCM samples are given in Table 3. The melting point of the pure paraffin wax and other samples with 0.5 mass%, 1.0 mass%, 2.0 mass% of nano-SiO2 in paraffin wax was found to be 63.74°C, 63.10°C, 62.72°C, and 62.08°C, respectively. In the same way, the solidification temperatures of the pure paraffin and the respective samples were found to be 57.01°C, 57.15°C, 57.54°C, and 59.41°C. It can be noticed that the dispersion of SiO2 nanoparticles in paraffin deliberately reduced the melting point and increased the solidification points. It indicates that the SiO2 nanoparticles acted as the nucleation agents and reduced the supercooling of the paraffin wax. Likewise, the reduction in latent heat did not follow the linearity and it may be due to the degree of mixing and agglomeration of SiO2 nanoparticles in base PCM. The identical trend is reported in the work of Karaipekli et al. (2017). Hence, it must be kept in mind while the selection of mass% of the nanoparticles for a thermal storage application as considerable increase in mass% of nanoparticles deteriorates the storage capacity of the PCMs.

sections.heading: TGA analysis
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analysis of the paraffin wax and the nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM samples were accompanied, by heating 5.5 mg of each sample at the rate of 10°C/min from 30°C to 450°C in nitrogen atmosphere. The heating rate of 10°C has been selected based on the similar previous researches (AlMaadeed et al. 2015; Mehrali et al. 2013). Figure 6 shows the result of the TGA analysis. It can be perceived that the plot shows the same trend for all the samples. However, the beginning and ending points of degradation temperature have been considerably increased by the addition of SiO2 nanoparticles with paraffin wax. The thermal degradation initiated at 142°C, 157°C, 159°C, and 160°C and ended at 244°C, 262°C, 266°C, and 268°C for paraffin wax and other samples with 0.5 mass%, 1.0 mass%, 2.0 mass% of nano-SiO2 in paraffin wax, respectively. Similarly, the mass % of residues remained after the degradation was obtained as 0%, 0.2%, 0.6%, and 0.9%, respectively. Paraffin wax was removed at 260°C, and all other samples were completely degraded at 450°C. The result ascertained that the dispersion of SiO2 nanoparticles expressively delayed the thermal decomposition of base paraffin wax as reported by Rao et al. (2014) and Karaipekli et al. (2017).
Figure 5. DSC results of nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM samples.

sections.heading: Thermal conductivity measurement
sections.text:
Thermal conductivity of the nano-enhanced PCMs is purely depending on the degree of dispersion of the nanoparticles in the base PCM. The dispersion is contingent on the duration of stirring and ultrasonication of the mixture. The effective ultrasonication ensures the finest suspension of nanoparticles in the PCM, which will form the decent network to transfer heat to all the portion of the PCM rapidly (Jesumathy, Udayakumar, and Suresh 2012). The thermal conductivity of the samples, measured through the experimentation is presented in Figure 7. Thermal conductivity of the pure paraffin is 0.18, and it has been increased to 0.203, 0.221, and 0.24 for the samples with 0.5 mass%, 1.0 mass%, and 2.0 mass% of nano SiO2 in paraffin wax, respectively. Ji et al. (2012) acknowledged that the dispersion of multi-walled carbon nanotubes in palmitic acid increased thermal conductivity to 67%. Deng et al. (2016) concluded that the addition of silver nanowire in polyethylene glycol PCM scrupulously improved the thermal conductivity to 1130%, which is 11.3 times higher than the thermal conductivity of pure polyethylene glycol.
The percentage enhancement in thermal conductivity (k) of nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM was calculated as per the following equation,

The percentage enhancement in thermal conductivity of nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs found to be 12.78%, 22.78%, and 33.34%, respectively, compared to the pure paraffin wax as in Figure 8. Relatively, the percentage improvement in thermal conductivity of paraffin wax is not impressive at 2.0 mass% of SiO2 nanoparticles comparing to other lower mass%. Furthermore, the result shows that the thermal conductivity is increasing non-linearly with the mass% of nanoparticles. Mohamed et al. (2017) obtained the same pattern of result, when they conducted an experiment with paraffin wax and α nano alumina. The reason behind the non-linear variation of thermal conductivity is due to the uneven dispersion and random agglomeration of nanoparticles, when the mass% of nanoparticles is increased.

sections.text:

These uncertainties could be arisen due to the factors such as errors in calibration of the measuring instruments and accuracy of the instruments used. In order to ensure the correctness of the obtained result, a detailed uncertainty analysis was conducted using the mathematical expression proposed by Naghavi et al. sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, the nano-enhanced phase change materials had been prepared by dispersing different mass% of nano-SiO2 particles in paraffin wax and their thermal properties were investigated to make use of them as thermal energy storage medium in solar heating application. The four samples; 0 mass%, 0.5 mass%, 1.0 mass%, and 2.0 mass% of nano-SiO2 in paraffin wax had been prepared using two-step method. Each

sample was experimentally investigated by means of different experimental techniques such as field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and thermal conductivity test. The results are concluded as follows:
(1) 1. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) analysis ensured the distribution of nano-SiO2 particles in paraffin wax and formation homogenous mixture of nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs. (2) 2. The differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) results showed that the melting temperature of the nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs were reduced to 63.10°C, 62.72°C, and 62.08°C, respectively, and solidification temperature enhanced to 57.15°C, 57.54°C, and 59.41°C, respectively. This phenomenon ensures that the nano-SiO2 particles reduced the supercooling of the paraffin wax. On the other hand, the latent heat of the paraffin wax was reduced with the increased mass% of nano-SiO2 particles and the declination was maximum at 2.0 mass% of nano-SiO2 particles. (3) 3. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) results proved that the physical bonding strongly exists between the paraffin wax and nano-SiO2 particles. Also, it confirmed that the chemical structure of the paraffin wax is not affected by the addition of nano-SiO2 particles. (4) 4. Thermogravimetric analysis revealed that the incorporation of nano-SiO2 particles in paraffin wax increased the thermal degradation temperature of the paraffin wax; thereby it delayed the decomposition of paraffin wax to the high temperature. (5) 5. Thermal conductivity test exhibited that the thermal conductivity of the paraffin wax was enhanced to 12.78%, 22.78%, and 33.34%, respectively, for the samples with 0.5 mass%, 1.0 mass%, and 2.0 mass% of nano-SiO2 particles and at 2.0 mass%, the improvement was not perceptible compared to other samples with lower mass% of nano-SiO2 particles.
As a whole, the dispersion of low mass% nano-SiO2 particles improved the thermal properties of the paraffin wax to the greater extent and it is proposed to use nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM as an enhanced thermal energy storage medium in solar thermal applications.

sections.heading: Notes on contributors
sections.text:
P. Manoj Kumar received his M.E. with Distinction from Mahendra Engineering College, Salem during 2010. He is presently pursuing his Ph.D as a part time research scholar in Anna University, Chennai. He is having more than ten years of teaching experience and his research area is ‘Thermal energy storage in solar water heaters’. He published twelve research papers in reputed International Journals; fifty three papers in International and National Conferences; authored two books; published one patent. He delivered guest lectures on Solar Thermal Energy at various institutions. His research interests include solar thermal energy conversion, phase change materials, nano materials and thermal energy storage.
K. Mylsamy received his B.E. in Mechanical Engineering and M.E. from Kongu Engineering College, Perundurai during 1997 and 1998. He received Ph.D from Anna University, Chennai in 2011. He is having more than 21 years of teaching and research experience. He published sixteen research papers in reputed International Journals; authored two books; published one patent. He is the reviewer of four reputed International Journals. Presently, he is guiding six research scholars under Anna University, Chennai. His research interests include natural fiber composite materials, renewable energy and thermal energy storage.
P.T. Saravanakumar received his Ph.D in Mechanical Engineering from Anna University, Chennai in 2015. He has obtained his Master Degree in Energy Engineering from PSG College of Technology in 2001 and Bachelor Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Bharathiyar University in 1998. Also, he has completed MBA from Bharathiyar University in 2016. He is having 18 years of teaching and research experience. He published fourteen research papers in reputed International Journals and four books. He is the reviewer of two International Journals. He is the life time member in ISTE, IE and ISHRAE. He research interests include renewable energy, solar thermal systems and magneto hydro-dynamic fluids.

metadata.abstractText: This paper investigates the influence of low mass% SiO2 nanoparticles on the thermal properties of the paraffin wax for solar thermal energy storage applications. The four nano-SiO2/paraffin PCM samples containing, 0.0 mass %, 0.5 mass%, 1.0 mass%, and 2.0 mass% of SiO2 nanoparticles in paraffin wax were synthesized. The prepared nano-SiO2/paraffin PCMs were investigated with different experimental techniques to assess their thermal properties and physical structure. The analysis evidenced that the fusion of SiO2 nanoparticles with paraffin wax was homogeneous, and they enhanced the thermal conductivity of paraffin wax to 12.78%, 22.78%, and 33.34%, respectively, with the aforementioned mass% of SiO2 nanoparticles. Likewise, the dispersion of SiO2 nanoparticles prolonged the thermal degradation of paraffin wax without disturbing its chemical structure and also altered the melting and solidification temperature of the paraffin in a favorable manner. However, the latent heat of the paraffin wax was decreased with the increasing mass% of the nanoparticles and decrement is noteworthy for more than 1.0 mass% of SiO2 nanoparticles in paraffin wax. Altogether, the outcomes revealed that the enhancement of thermal properties were significant, when paraffin wax is supplemented with lowest mass% of SiO2 nanoparticles and to be appropriate for enhanced thermal energy storage.
